title: Contrapositive
description:
Prove the contrapositive law: if `P` implies `Q`, then `~Q` implies `~P`.

**Goal:** `forall P Q : Prop, (P -> Q) -> ~Q -> ~P`

The contrapositive is one of the most important logical principles. Remember that `~P` unfolds to `P -> False`, so after introducing all hypotheses you need to derive `False`.
hints: Use `intros` to introduce `P`, `Q`, `HPQ : P -> Q`, `HnQ : ~Q`, and `HP : P`
Apply `HnQ` â€” this reduces the goal from `False` to `Q`
Then apply `HPQ` to reduce `Q` to `P`, which you already have

solution:
Theorem contrapositive : forall P Q : Prop, (P -> Q) -> ~Q -> ~P.
Proof.
  intros P Q HPQ HnQ HP.
  apply HnQ.
  apply HPQ.
  exact HP.
Qed.
